bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to P.M. Hamer, January 6, 1942

div1.p: Hench is anxious to see the correspondence between the yellow fever board and the surgeon general's office, held by the National Archives.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to P.M. Hamer, January 6, 1942

opener.dateline:
January 6, 1942 Mr. P. M. Hamer
Chief of the Division of Reference
National Archives
Washington, D. C.

div1.p:
Last Spring I had the privilege of visiting the National Archives
in connection with the study I have been making on the history of the conquest
of yellow fever. Since then, with the help of Generals Kean and Ireland of
Washington, Chief Clerk Brooke of the Surgeon General's office and others,
I have been trying to trace down the correspondence between the office of the
Surgeon General and the members of the Yellow Fever Board in Cuba for the
years 1900 and 1901. There are many letters and telegrams between Generals
Sternberg and his associates in Washington and Walter Reed and Drs. Lazear,
Carroll, Agramonte and others in Havana. Mr. Brooke now informs me that these
records have been transferred recently from Fort Myer to the National Archives
and he assures me I will be able to see them there when I come to Washington
next week for a few days.

I expect to arrive at the Willard Hotel in Washington about January 13
and hope to visit your office in the Archives shortly thereafter. As I have been
trying for at least a year to trace these, I am delighted to know that I can now
see them and I will certainly appreciate any courtesy you can extend to me.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
